entryFree:
سَذَابٌ ذ , said to be an arabicized word, because [it is asserted that] س and ذ are not combined in any Arabic word; [and if so, سُذْبَةٌ also, men-
tioned above, is arabicized;] but in some of the books on plants it is written with the unpointed د; (TA;) i. q. فَيْجَنٌ, (K,) which is an ancient Greek word, (TA,) [i. e. πήγανο, meaning Rue;] a well-known بَقْل [or kind of herb], (K,) having properties described in the medical books. (TA.)
